The usual answer is to use a DFA. A DFA is a deterministic finite automaton that processes input "on the fly". It is very easy to create a DFA, and it is also very easy to interrogate it.
Here's an example of a DFA that does the job you need:

The DFA is pretty simple: It has three states. The initial state is the empty string, and the target state is "the empty string". The transition function is given by the following table:

                             Empty
                         Empty string
                             Empty string
                             Empty string
                      The empty string is represented by the empty list.
                      Let's go through the table:
                       -- Empty string -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string
                         Empty -> Empty string

So now you can test the DFA. First, put the DFA in the state "empty string" (the initial state), and then run it. It will eventually reach the state "the empty string". So the string "hello world" is accepted.

    # Find the p-value for each sample

    max_p_value = np.argmax(np.abs(np.diff(np.diff(df_test, axis=1))))

Maltese social science research Centre (MSSRC)

The Maltese Social Science Research Centre (MSSRC) is a research centre run by the University of Malta, under the supervision of the Department of Social Sciences (DSS). The centre supports a number of research projects, and also offers courses in social science for students.

The centre was established in 1996, and is one of the three social science research centres run by the Maltese government. The research centre undertakes a wide range of research projects, including those in ethnography, qualitative research, and survey research.

Facilities include research studios, a lecture theatre, a library, and an archive. The centre also holds a number of conference rooms, and has a relationship with the British Social Attitudes Survey (BSSRS), and the British Household Panel Survey (BHPS). The centre also supports a number of inter-university partnerships (IUP) with the University of Malta and the University of Essex.

abstract: 'We consider a kinetic system exhibiting a finite-time singularity. A large population of particles is assigned to a large number of links; these links are collectively moved by the particle trajectories. The development of the system results in a critical trajectory for the moving links. This trajectory contains a fixed point of the dynamics and we show that this fixed point is an invariant of the system. This invariant is an infinite-dimensional Lie algebra. The topology of this algebra can be determined through a linear extension of the system. This extension contains the original system and, in particular, it may have a finite-time singularity. We show that this linear extension is not equivalent to the original system, and that the original system is not equivalent to the linear extension. We also show that the original system has a finite-time singularity in the sense that its invariant is the space of invariant distributions for the linear extension.'

Both comments and pings are currently closed.The effect of carbon dioxide on compound ionization potential in mixtures of carbon dioxide and sulfur hexafluoride.
The effects of carbon dioxide (CO(2)) and sulfur hexafluoride (SF(6)) on the ionization potential (IP) of a series of organic compounds in mixtures are examined. The IP is determined by the following relations: IP = IP(CO(2)) + IP(SF(6)) + IP(SF(6)/CO(2)) + IP(CO(2)/SF(6)) + IP(SF(6)/CO(2)/SF(6)) + IP(CO(2)/SF(6)/CO(2)) and IP = IP(SF(6)/CO(2)) + IP(SF(6)/CO(2)/SF(6)). We show that for some organic compounds, IP(CO(2))/IP(SF(6)) values are appreciably larger than IP(SF(6)/CO(2)). The effect of CO(2) on IP in mixtures is primarily due to the larger IP(CO(2))/IP(SF(6)) value of the mixture. For other compounds, IP(CO(2)/SF(6)) values are appreciably larger than IP(SF(6)/CO(2)). The effects of CO(2) and SF(6) on IP in mixtures are not fully understood. Some of the effects of CO(2) are due to the greater IP for the CO(2) molecule compared to the SF(6) molecule, while the other effects of CO(2) and SF(6) are due to the greater IP for the SF(6) molecule compared to the CO(2) molecule. The effect of CO(2) on IP in mixtures is most important for compounds with IP values

abstract: 'We study the evolution of an accretion disk around a massive black hole in a nonspinning, axisymmetric potential. We assume that the black hole is surrounded by an accretion disk, which is significantly distorted due to the black hole’s spin. We consider two types of accretion disk perturbations. In the first type, we assume that the disk is perturbed by a constant, radial flow. In the second type, we assume that the disk is perturbed by a constant, azimuthal flow, which is opposite to the magnetic field. We obtain analytical and numerical solutions for both types of perturbations. We discuss the evolution of the disk, and find that the disk is not in hydrostatic equilibrium, and evolves into a steadily rotating disk, which is similar to the evolution of a magnetized accretion disk. We also find that the accretion disk around a spinning black hole can be completely disrupted when the black hole is close to the critical rotation, and the accretion disk is not disturbed by the black hole’s spin even if the disk is perturbed by a constant, radial flow.'

He had a clinical presentation mimicking MS and MRI findings of MS. He was treated with combination therapy of interferon beta-1a and glatiramer acetate. He had a complete remission of his disease. He remained relapse free for three years. No relapse was observed during the two years following the withdrawal of the therapy. This case shows that anti-aquaporin 4 antibody should be considered in the diagnosis of RRMS. Q:

How to remove the appended character in a string?

How to remove the appended character in a string?
For example, if the input string is "123.abc". I want the output to be "123".
I tried the code below but it doesn't seem to work.
s = "123.abc"
z = s.split()

print(z)

A:

You can use str.join:
>>> s = "123.abc"
>>> s.join("")
'123'

It removes the first . from the end of the string.

A:

You can use split but using splitext
s = "123.abc"
s1 = s.split()
s2 = s.split('.')
print s1.join(s2)

Output is
123.

A:

Use the string.join function:
import string

s = "123.abc"

s = s.split()
print s.join("")

Output:
123.

NOTE:
This is because the split function is expecting a sequence of strings to be returned rather than a single string

This is the shortest solution, but in my opinion the most beautiful.
Using the string.join function:
import string

s = "123.abc"
s = s.split()
print s.join("")

Output:
123

Using regular expressions:
import re

s = "123.abc"
s = s.split()
print s.replace(r'[.].*', '').join()

Output:
123

Can you give me at least 3 examples from each of these categories of programming languages?
assistant_prompt:
(1)
-- 
2.0.0-rc1

Copyright (C) 2006-2018 Free Software Foundation, Inc.

This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.  There is NO
warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.

A:

There are a few good uses of compiled languages which are not JIT-compiled.  Here are some examples.

If you have a large number of variables in a program, you can compile it to a module.  The module contains many functions, and each function is in a separate file.  Then, you can use the module as a library to access the functions.  This is handy for things like game servers or 3D engines or garbage collection for a program.  
If you want to run your program only on Linux, you can compile it to a module which can be used as a script to start the program.  The script doesn't need to be written in the language of the compiled program.  This is handy for things like scripting languages like Python or Perl.  
If you want to run your program on Windows, you can compile it to a module which contains the functions that you want to use.  You can use the functions to call the program and execute it.  
If you want to share your programs, you can compile it to a library.  You can then share libraries between multiple programs.  For example, if I have a C++ program, I can compile it to a library and use the libraries in other programs.  Then, I can use the libraries in other programs in order to get a more complicated program.

Pneumonia is also the major cause of hospitalization for children under five years old \[[@CR2]--[@CR6]\].

Ntaya \[[@CR7]\] presented a systematic review of the literature on the factors that predispose children to pneumonia. Three important factors were identified: age, anthropometry, and malnutrition.

The first factor is age, age is one of the most important determinants of pneumonia. Children with a decreased concentration of lung fluid, a decreased number of alveoli, and a decreased number of alveoli per cubic millimeter of lung \[[@CR8]\] are at risk of developing pneumonia.

The second factor is anthropometric factors. The anthropometric factors include height, weight, chest-to-hip ratio (CHR), and head circumference. The mean value of CHR is between 0.60 and 0.84 for children aged five to 18 months. Children with high CHR have a higher risk of pneumonia \[[@CR9]\]. In addition, high body mass index (BMI) is also a risk factor for pneumonia. Low BMI is associated with pneumonia, as well as a high risk of malnutrition \[[@CR10], [@CR11]\].

The third factor is malnutrition. Malnutrition is a risk factor for pneumonia, as well as a risk factor for hospitalization \[[@CR9], [@CR12]\]. Malnutrition is defined as BMI equal to or less than the fifth percentile, as determined by the World Health Organization (WHO) \[[@CR13]\]. In the under five population, the prevalence of malnutrition is around 25% \[[@CR14]\].

Although the WHO has developed a set of guidelines to describe the nutritional status of children, there is no consensus among countries over how to measure, diagnose, and treat malnutrition in children

assistant_prompt:
. What is the difference between the two derivatives?

A:

A derivative is a function that has an associated function and the associated function is, as you know, the function that you want to differentiate. The function of the derivative at any point is the second function.
The notation for the derivative is the differential notation. The notation for the second function is the partial differential notation. Where the derivative is being used is to differentiate the second function that you want to differentiate.
You can write the difference between a function and its derivative as the sum of its partial derivatives. For example, your function is
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f(x,y) = x \\
g(x,y) = y
\end{array}
$$
The partial derivatives of this function are
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f_x = f(x,y)  \\
f_y = f(x,y) - f(x)
\end{array}
$$
The sum of these partial derivatives is
$$
\begin{array}{c}
2f_y = f(x,y) - f(x)  \\
2f_x = f(x,y) - 2f(x)
\end{array}
$$
So the difference between $f$ and its derivative is
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f(x,y) - f(x) - f_x = f_y - f(x)  \\
g(x,y) - g(x) - g_x = f_y - g(x)
\end{array}
$$
Noting that the definition of the derivative is that it is the derivative of the second function, I can see that we've used the partial differential notation. The partial differential notation is defined as
$$
\begin{array}{c}
f_y = f(x,y) - f(x)
\end{array}
$$
To evaluate this difference, we need to differentiate the second function.
$$
\begin{array}{c}
g(x,y) - g(x) - g_x = f_y - g(x)  \\
f_y = f(x,y) - f(x) - f_x
\end{array}

Defects in the blood--brain barrier (BBB) can be a common complication of multiple sclerosis (MS) that are characterized by the presence of aggregates of leukocytes, erythrocytes, lymphocytes, and monocytes in the brain parenchyma, and can also lead to severe neurological deficits \[[@CIT0001]--[@CIT0003]\].

The BBB represents a highly selective and specialized barrier, consisting of cerebral microvascular endothelial cells, pericytes, and neurons \[[@CIT0004], [@CIT0005]\]. The cerebral microvascular endothelium is responsible for the formation of the tight junctions between adjacent endothelial cells. The tight junctions are formed by occluding the endothelial cell membrane at the cell borders and prevent the passage of molecules, including immunoglobulins, lymphocytes, and other inflammatory cells, across the endothelial cell membrane and into the brain parenchyma. The pericytes are associated with the basal lamina of the endothelial cells and are responsible for the maintenance of the integrity of the BBB, by covering the endothelial cells and forming a continuous basement membrane \[[@CIT0004], [@CIT0006], [@CIT0007]\]. The neurons are connected to the basal lamina by gap junctions \[[@CIT0006], [@CIT0008]\].

The BBB is affected by the immune system, in particular, autoimmune diseases, and it may be affected by pathogens in the blood \[[@CIT0009], [@CIT0010]\]. The BBB is also affected by diseases of the central nervous system (CNS), including MS. The microenvironment of the CNS is composed of the extracellular matrix (ECM) and the endolymphatic sac, the CSF, and the choroid plexus \[[@CIT0011]\]. The microvessels of the CNS are surrounded by the ECM and lined by pericytes \[[@CIT0012]\]. The endothelial cells are also surrounded

Drug-induced immunophenotyping of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.
Elevated peripheral blood progenitor cells are predictive of a better outcome in patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and they are used for the selection of high-dose therapy in front-line treatment of CLL. However, in some patients, the response to therapy is suboptimal. In these cases, disease mechanisms other than reduction in the proliferative capacity of the CLL cells may be involved. The aim of this study was to investigate whether the immune system plays a role in the pathogenesis of CLL. Bone marrow and peripheral blood samples from patients with CLL and a control group were analyzed by flow cytometry. Neutrophil and monocyte counts were significantly higher in the patient group, whereas the lymphocyte counts were significantly lower. Chemokines, granzymes, and perforin were significantly higher in the patient group. The percentage of CD3+ cells and of CD19+CD20+ cells was significantly higher in the patient group. Peripheral blood CD3+ cells and CD3+CD4+CD8+ cells were significantly higher in the patient group. The percentage of CD19+CD20+ cells was significantly higher in the patient group. The percentage of peripheral blood CD4+CD8+ cells was significantly higher in the patient group. The percentage of CD3+CD4+CD8+ cells was significantly higher in the patient group. The percentage of CD3+CD4+CD8+ cells was significantly higher in the patient group. This study suggests that the immune system plays an important role in the pathogenesis of CLL and that the immune system may be one of the factors that contribute to the poor outcome of CLL patients.--
